html:
Detroit Lions receiver Amon-Ra St. Brown knew this was a risk.

His prized offensive coordinator leaving for a division rival? The Chicago Bears had not reached a deal with Ben Johnson last week, when St. Brown and his brother Equanimeous St. Brown hosted Bears quarterback Caleb Williams on their podcast.

But the rumblings were enough that Amon-Ra St. Brown joked last week: â€œJust so you know, I told Ben, â€˜Caleb is f***ing trash.â€™â€

â€œThatâ€™s all right,â€ Williams deadpanned in response. â€œWhat he does with that information, thatâ€™s all good.â€

Amon-Ra St. Brown doubled down: â€œCalebâ€™s a diva. Heâ€™s a selfish motherf***er, wants to do everything on his own, thinks heâ€™s the smartest guy in the world, not coachable.â€

His brother rolled his eyes: â€œAmon, heâ€™s gone. Say goodbye.â€

Ben Johnson is reportedly a top candidate for multiple head coach openings, including Chicago, and Amon-Ra doesnâ€™t want to see him leave ğŸ˜… pic.twitter.com/Xj0bbTEtC8

â€” St. Brown Podcast (@StBrownPodcast) January 16, 2025

By Monday, Johnson was.

The Bears reached a deal to hire Johnson as their next head coach Monday afternoon, according to multiple media reports, including a post from the coaching agency representing Johnson. The team made the official announcement Tuesday, and Bears fans have reason to celebrate.

Because while a front office whose words and actions donâ€™t always align cited different goals for its coaching search, the success of the Bearsâ€™ next hire will hinge most strongly on one facet: maximizing the potential of Williams, whom they selected first overall in the 2024 NFL Draft.

The three offensive coordinators and two head coaches he navigated as a rookie stunted that goal. Now, a high-ceiling talent has the chance to recover and grow in his sophomore year.

Williams learned, through a tumultuous rookie year, how powerful stability could be. Hiring a head coach who calls plays, and thus wonâ€™t bolt for a promotion elsewhere, can create an offensive advantage. So yes, consider him a fan of the Johnson hire.

â€œSelfishly, I want an offensive-minded guy,â€ Williams told the St. Brown brothers, â€œso I can build with him and be with that coach for the next 19, 17, 15 years.â€

What Williams, Bears offense might look like under Johnson

Just before he admitted he wanted an offensive head coach, Williams mentioned he wanted a head coach who is â€œstrong-mindedâ€ and â€œa leader of men.â€ His franchise touted that emphatically during a head coach searching process that included interviews (some virtual, some in person) with 17 announced candidates.

But the Bears did not commit in recent weeks to hiring an offensive head coach. Team president Kevin Warren insisted it was important to enter the search undecided, while general manager Ryan Poles declined to confirm hiring an offensive coach for Williams was necessary.

â€œFor a young quarterback, obviously there's an ideal fit, but at the end of the day, you gotta look at all the characteristics of what you're looking for in the head coach,â€ Poles said Jan. 7. â€œAnd then you got to see what's the best bundle of those to bring in the building. Obviously we're talking about leadership, accountability, some of those important things that carry over regardless of what the situation is. Those have to be there. To ignore those just to go to the other side [of scheme strength] I think is a bad deal, too.

â€œSo really it's the candidate that has the best collection of all of those things, and yes, the development of a young quarterback is gonna be a huge factor in that.â€

Teams have learned the downfalls of failing to support a rookie quarterback, from Jacksonville Jaguars quarterback Trevor Lawrence translating seemingly generational talent into average performance, to the litany of quarterbacks the New York Jets have drafted and wrecked, either permanently or temporarily (welcome back, Geno Smith and Sam Darnold).

Williams completed 62.5% of passes for 3,541 yards, 20 touchdowns and six interceptions as a rookie. His 87.8 passer rating ranked 25th in the league. Williamsâ€™ attempts to make plays, paired with shoddy protection, led to a league-high 68 sacks for a league-high 466 yards.

With Johnson, the Bears hope they can protect Williams better and give him better schematic wrinkles to succeed. The architect of the Lionsâ€™ No. 1 scoring offense is no sure bet, but league sources expect a significant upgrade.

One former offensive coordinator, whoâ€™s now an NFC assistant, expects an uptick in play-action passes after the Lions ranked first in the league with 36.6% this season compared to the Bearsâ€™ 30th-most 17%. Williams could see more time under center, too, after the Lions ranked last with 16 attempts in shotgun compared to the Bearsâ€™ 37.

â€œItâ€™ll be dramatic change,â€ the former coordinator told Yahoo Sports. â€œMore of a pro-style deal than what they were trying to run this year. Gonna have to retrain the QB.â€

An NFC assistant who has worked with a first-round quarterback pick expected some schematic continuity after considering the depths of coaching trees, and some zone-run influence overlap between Johnsonâ€™s time under Adam Gase and the Los Angeles Ramsâ€™ Sean McVay, who influenced 2024 Bears coordinators Shane Waldron and Thomas Brown.

Williams is focused less on specific scheme and more on how a head coach can offer an edge or a disadvantage on macro considerations.

â€œSo I can also learn and grow and things like that from him,â€ Williams said on the St. Brown Podcast. â€œ[Someone whoâ€™s] good with the clock, good with helping control the game â€¦ helping find the right guys to help win championships.â€

Ben Johnson answers some questions already â€” while others remain to be seen

Did the Bears find the â€œleader of menâ€ they cited? Itâ€™s too soon to say.

While narratives surrounding Detroit didnâ€™t knock Johnsonâ€™s leadership, his schematic reputation certainly supersedes word of his presence.

League perspective on Johnsonâ€™s readiness for the head coaching role is mixed.

Near-unanimous opinion says heâ€™s a brilliant schematic mind who will be an advantage for any coaching staff. Six seasons in the NFC North will contribute to his game-planning edge as he stays in the division with his new role.

How Johnsonâ€™s leadership strengths complement his creativity remains to be seen.

â€œHe's a phenomenal coordinator, he's a phenomenal schemer, play designer,â€ one AFC general manager told Yahoo Sports on Monday. â€œAnd look, maybe you put him in a position where he's like [San Francisco 49ers head coach] Kyle [Shanahan] where you're like, â€˜Hey, we're really hiring you to be the OC-plusâ€™ because he's just that good at the role.â€™

â€œMy inclination is that that's gonna be a tougher transition for him in the head-coaching seat. I think he's probably smart enough to manage everything in terms of designing the offense and running the team so maybe it doesn't end up mattering. But I would actually have some pretty significant reservations there with him.â€

One key trait Lions players cited in Johnsonâ€™s personality is his intensity. While that may mesh with differing degrees of success across the league, Williams said he seeks that with the Bears.

Sure, St. Brown said in jest how difficult Williams is to coach. But the quarterback himself acknowledged he can be particular and wants a coach who will embrace that.

â€œA dude thatâ€™s got a fire to him,â€ Williams said. â€œI donâ€™t want people [who don't] have a fire. I think I've got a fire about me that certain people canâ€™t coach or certain people canâ€™t be around or it doesnâ€™t work in that way. So I think thatâ€™s a big part of it.â€

The Bears, with their hire, indicated they think so, too.
